The IHR, in their version adopted in 2005, have been amended twice – in 2014 and 2022 (the most-recent amendments will come into force in May 2024). The newest proposed amendments come in response to the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. (1) Liechtenstein and the Holy See are State Parties to the IHR but not Member States of WHO.

am.reference: Impact: Micronutrient deficiencies can cause several serious health issues. A lack of iron, folate and vitamins B12 and A can lead to anaemia. Anaemia is a condition in which there is a reduced number of red blood cells or haemoglobin concentration, causing fatigue, weakness, shortage of breath and dizziness. This can further lead to difficulties in functioning in work, education and community engagement. An estimated 42% of children under 5 years of age and 40% of pregnant women worldwide are anaemic.

am.reference: Chikungunya Overview: Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral disease that causes fever and severe joint pain. The disease was first recognized in 1952 during an outbreak in southern Tanzania. It is a ribonucleic acid (RNA) virus that belongs to the alphavirus genus of the family Togaviridae. The name “chikungunya” derives from a word in the Kimakonde language of southern Tanzania, meaning “to become contorted”, and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain (arthralgia).

am.prediction: Digital Health Summary: At present, digital technologies have become integrated with everyday life, and the people of the world have never before been as interconnected as they are now. Innovation, especially in the digital sphere, is progressing at an unprecedented and previously unseen level. However, its application to improve public health has so far not been fully utilized, and there remains a wide scope for using digital health solutions. The World Health Organization is working to accelerate global health and well-being by harnessing digital technologies and the power of health innovation.
am.reference: Digital health Overview: Digital technologies are now integral to daily life, and the world’s population has never been more interconnected. Innovation, particularly in the digital sphere, is happening at unprecedented scale. Even so, its application to improve the health of populations remains largely untapped, and there is immense scope for use of digital health solutions. WHO is harnessing the power of digital technologies and health innovation to accelerate global attainment of health and the well-being.

am.prediction: Human-made ponds are the main source of transmission. The occurrence of guinea worm disease varies by season, depending on climate, and in Africa it appears in two broad patterns. In the Sahelian zone, transmission generally occurs in the rainy season (from May to August). In humid savanna and forest areas, it occurs predominantly in the highly sunny dry season (from December to January). Treatment: There is no medication of any kind to prevent or cure this disease.
am.reference: Human-made ponds are the main source of transmission. Guinea-worm disease is seasonal, occurring with two broad patterns found in endemic areas of Africa, depending on climatic factors. In the Sahelian zone, transmission generally occurs in the rainy season (May to August). In the humid savanna and forest zone, the peak occurs in the dry season (September to January). Treatment: No drug is available to prevent or heal this parasitic disease.

am.prediction: Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is very common in low- and middle-income countries where people do not have access to clean and reliable water sources and have a high risk of exposure to contaminated food. There is a safe and effective vaccine to prevent hepatitis A. Most hepatitis A infections are mild; most people fully recover and develop lifelong immunity that protects them from more serious disease. However, these infections can occasionally become severe and life-threatening due to liver failure.
am.reference: Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is most common is low- and middle-income countries due to reduced access to clean and reliable water sources and the increased risk of contaminated food. A safe and effective vaccine is available to prevent hepatitis A. Most HAV infections are mild, with the majority of people recovering fully and developing immunity to further infection. However, these infections can also rarely be severe and life threatening due to the risk of liver failure.

am.prediction: General overview of volcanic eruptions: A volcano is an opening in the Earth’s crust where eruptions occur. There are about 1,500 active volcanoes around the world. When volcanoes erupt, they can release hot, dangerous gases, ash, lava, and rocks. Especially in areas where many people live, they can cause severe damage to human life and property. Volcanic activity and wildfires between 1998 and 2017 affected 6.2 million people, and about 2,400 people also died.
am.reference: Volcanic eruptions Overview: A volcano is a vent in the Earth’s crust from which eruptions occur. There are about 1500 potentially active volcanoes worldwide. When volcanoes erupt they can spew hot, dangerous gases, ash, lava and rock that can cause disastrous loss of life and property, especially in heavily populated areas. Volcanic activities and wildfires affected 6.2 million people and caused nearly 2400 deaths between 1998-2017.

am.prediction: Paralysis can occur rapidly within a few hours after infection with the disease. Among those who become paralyzed, 5–10% die because their respiratory muscles stop moving. The virus can spread quickly through contaminated feces from infected people (usually children), especially in areas with poor sanitation and hygiene. Treatment: There is no medicine for polio; it can only be prevented by vaccination. When the polio vaccine is given multiple times, it can protect a child throughout the appropriate age period.
am.reference: Paralysis can occur as rapidly as within a few hours of infection. Of those paralysed, 5-10% die when their breathing muscles become immobilized. The virus is shed by infected people (usually children) through faeces, where it can spread quickly, especially in areas with poor hygiene and sanitation systems. Treatment: There is no cure for polio; it can only be prevented by immunization. The polio vaccine, given multiple times, can protect a child for life.

am.reference: Impact: Micronutrient deficiencies can cause several serious health issues. A lack of iron, folate and vitamins B12 and A can lead to anaemia. Anaemia is a condition in which there is a reduced number of red blood cells or haemoglobin concentration, causing fatigue, weakness, shortage of breath and dizziness. This can further lead to difficulties in functioning in work, education and community engagement. An estimated 42% of children under 5 years of age and 40% of pregnant women worldwide are anaemic.

am.prediction: Chikungunya Summary: Chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted by mosquitoes that causes fever and severe joint pain. The disease was first recognized in 1952 during an outbreak in southern Tanzania. It is an RNA virus of the alphavirus genus in the Togaviridae family, which has a single-stranded, positive-sense genome. The name “chikungunya” comes from the Kimakonde language spoken in southern Tanzania, and it means “to become contorted,” describing the bent posture of patients suffering from joint pain (arthralgia).
am.reference: Chikungunya Overview: Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral disease that causes fever and severe joint pain. The disease was first recognized in 1952 during an outbreak in southern Tanzania. It is a ribonucleic acid (RNA) virus that belongs to the alphavirus genus of the family Togaviridae. The name “chikungunya” derives from a word in the Kimakonde language of southern Tanzania, meaning “to become contorted”, and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain (arthralgia).

am.prediction:
Since the vaccine does not provide 100% protection, even vaccinated travelers must be careful not to consume food and water that may be contaminated.  

Signs and treatment  
Salmonella typhi lives only in humans. In people with typhoid fever, the bacteria enter the intestine and eventually seep into the blood. Because of this, the resulting illness usually has no clinical distinction from other febrile diseases.
am.reference: Even vaccinated travellers should take care to avoid consumption of potentially contaminated food and water as vaccination does not confer 100% protection. Symptoms and treatment Salmonella Typhi lives only in humans. In persons with typhoid fever the bacteria enter through the intestinal tract and eventually invade the bloodstream. The resulting illness is often clinically non-distinguishable from other febrile illnesses.
